Address.Line1: Broad Institute of MIT and Harvard
Address.Line2: 415 Main Street, Cambridge, MA 02142 United States

HomePage.Title: If you or your family member has a rare and genetically undiagnosed condition, you may be eligible to join a patient-driven research study aimed at discovering the genes underlying your family’s rare disease.
HomePage.Text: The Rare Genomes Project (RGP) at the Broad Institute of MIT and Harvard is a patient-driven research study led by genomics experts and clinicians who believe that the latest advances in genomic sequencing are changing medicine and should be accessible to families with rare and undiagnosed conditions.

Discovery.Title: Aid Discovery
Discovery.Subtitle: More than half of the genes underlying rare diseases remain undiscovered.
Discovery.Text: By participating in the Rare Genomes Project, you can help researchers identify the genes that cause rare disease. If you are eligible for the study, we will use genomic sequencing to look for the cause of the rare, undiagnosed disease in your family.

Answers.Title: Find Answers
Answers.Subtitle: Your family’s diagnosis belongs to you.
Answers.Text: If we find a genetic change that may be the cause of the rare disease in your family, we will confirm it in a clinical lab and work with your local doctor to return the result to you.

Involved.Title: Get Involved
Involved.Subtitle: Join the research community.
Involved.Text: The Rare Genomes Project is supported by The Broad Institute of MIT and Harvard in partnership with patients and advocates like you. We believe that families should be at the center of research involving their diseases, and encourage the involvement of families and the advocacy groups that support them throughout the study.

Data.Title: Share Data
Data.Subtitle: Data sharing is crucial for improving diagnosis rates of rare disease worldwide.
Data.Text1: The genetic information generated in this project will be shared with other scientists to ensure it has the widest possible impact. Your genetic data can help families like yours and improve scientists’ understanding of rare disease. Learn more about our data sharing policies

One.Title: Tell us your story
One.Text3: to see a broad overview of the study and learn how you can start an application where you can tell us about the history of rare disease in your family. The information will be reviewed by our study team, and eligible families will be invited to participate. We will contact you to arrange a detailed discussion about the study and send you a consent form.

Two.Title: Submit a sample
Two.Text: Once enrolled, we will mail a pre-paid sample collection kit directly to you and your family. We will also ask you more about medical history and ask for copies of medical records, including any prior genetic test results.

Three.Title: Discover
Three.Text: Through DNA sequencing, we may discover the genetic cause of the rare disease in your family and will work with you and your doctor to return important results to you. We will also share de-identified data broadly with the scientific community to empower discoveries in rare disease research.

Quote.Text1: "This research project really understands the importance of bringing patients in as partners and engaging patients in a novel way. It's critical to do that because
Quote.Text2: patients are often the ones that start driving the research
Quote.Author: -Matt Might, Caregiver and Director, Hugh Kaul Precision Medicine Institute

Partners.Title: Our advocacy partners
Partners.Rare: Rare science accelerating cures for rare kids

LastSection.Title: You can be the driving force behind rare disease research.
LastSection.Text: Many thanks to the National Institutes of Health (NIH), the Muscular Dystrophy Association (MDA), Illumina, Inc., Broad Institute, the Silicon Valley Community Foundation, and Shriners Hospitals for Children for their financial support of our project.

AboutUsPage.Title: Our Story
AboutUsPage.InfoBox: We are a tight-knit team of researchers, clinicians, software developers, genetic counselors, and coordinators, who believe that the latest advances in genome sequencing technology are changing the world, and that they should be available to every rare and undiagnosed family.

Intro.Text1: We created the Rare Genomes Project to enable patients with undiagnosed, suspected genetic conditions to participate in genomic research regardless of where they live, to engage participants as partners in the research process, and to turn genomic data into clinically meaningful answers for families.
Intro.Text2: Improving our understanding of the rarest genetic conditions requires combining the experiences of patients and families directly with genomic research. By reaching out nationwide and empowering the rare and undiagnosed community to donate a sample and their story, we hope to better understand the genetic basis of all undiagnosed diseases.

Broad.Title: The Broad Institute
Broad.Section1: The Broad Institute of MIT and Harvard is a non-profit, academic research institution based in Cambridge, Massachusetts, focused on using genomic data to better understand human health and disease. The Broad is home to sequencing facilities that can produce and analyze genetic data at the rate of an entire genome every 12 minutes—more systematically and at a larger scale than any other facility. We have developed new advances in genome sequencing and analysis technology that have allowed us to find the genetic changes at the root of the diseases of thousands of patients. The Broad’s research philosophy is centered on large-scale collaborative research and open data sharing.

Section2.Text1: Despite these exciting improvements in diagnosis, however, the vast majority of rare disease patients still remain undiagnosed.
Section2.Text2: The Broad is committed to changing this for all rare disease patients
Section2.Text3: and we are sharing our resources with the research community at large to make sure that we are advancing rare disease research worldwide. For more information about the Broad Institute, go to

Section1.name: Daniel MacArthur, PhD
Section1.bio: Daniel is a Principal Investigator on the Rare Genomes Project and the Co-Director for the Broad Center for Mendelian Genomics. He is also a group leader within the Analytic and Translational Genetics Unit (ATGU) at Massachusetts General Hospital, Assistant Professor at Harvard Medical School and the Associate Director of Medical and Population Genetics at the Broad Institute. He is a strong advocate and pioneer of open science and data sharing. He lead the creation and release of the Exome Aggregation Consortium (ExAC) and Genome Aggregation Database (gnomAD).

Section1.name: Heidi Rehm, PhD, FACMG
Section1.bio: Heidi is a Principal Investigator on the Rare Genomes Project and is the Co-Director for the Broad Center for Mendelian Genomics. She is also the Chief Genomics Officer in the Department of Medicine at Massachusetts General Hospital and a Professor at Harvard Medical School. She built and until 2018 directed the  Laboratory for Molecular Medicine at Partners Healthcare Personalized Medicine. She is a strong advocate and pioneer of open science and data sharing, through leadership roles in ClinGen and the Global Alliance for Genomics and Health.

Section1.name: Anne O’Donnell-Luria, MD, PhD
Section1.bio: Anne is the Medical Director on the Rare Genomes Project. She is the Associate Director for Rare Disease Genomics at the Broad Institute. She obtained her MD/PhD from Columbia University and is a board-certified Clinical Genetics and Metabolism physician and pediatrician who sees patients at Boston Children's Hospital. She is an Instructor at Harvard Medical School.

Section1.name: Melanie O'Leary, MS, LGC
Section1.bio: Melanie is the Operations Lead for the Rare Genomes Project and a Senior Clinical Project Manager at the Broad Institute. She oversees the operational aspects of the project and will lead the return of results to families enrolled in the study. She is a licensed, board-certified Genetic Counselor who has worked in a variety of clinical, research, and clinical laboratory settings.

Section2.name: Harindra Arachchi, MBA
Section2.bio: Harindra is a Software Engineer working on building tools to help study rare genetic diseases, including Matchbox, which is used to match families around the world who have pathogenic variants in the same genes.

Section2.name: Samantha Baxter, MS, LGC
Section2.bio: Samantha is a licensed, board-certified Genetic Counselor for the Rare Genomes Project and Senior Clinical Genomics Specialist at the Broad Institute. She has worked in the area of cardiovascular and laboratory genetics and is interested in data sharing, particularly in improving methods for effectively sharing phenotype information.

Section2.name: Jaime Chang
Section2.bio: Jaime is a Senior Project Coordinator for the Rare Genomes Project. She was previously a laboratory research associate and also has prior marketing experience in healthcare and biotech.

Section2.name: Katherine Chao
Section2.bio: Katherine is a Genomic Variant Analyst conducting exome and genome analyses for families with rare disease. Before joining the Broad, she worked in the NIH’s Undiagnosed Diseases Program.

Section2.name: Beryl Cummings
Section2.bio: Beryl is a Genomic Analyst and Graduate Student from the Biomedical and Biological Sciences Program at Harvard who works on using RNA sequencing data to interpret the functional impact of human genetic variation.

Section2.name: Eleina England, MS
Section2.bio: Eleina is a Genomic Variant Analyst who performs exome and genome analyses for families with rare disease. She has a masters in biology, and before joining the Broad, she worked in research and diagnostic laboratory settings.

Section2.name: Julia Goodrich, PhD
Section2.bio: Julia is a Genomic Analyst and Postdoctoral Fellow interested in developing methods to improve the diagnosis of rare genetic diseases. She is currently focused on detecting structural variants that cause rare disease.

Section2.name: Monica Hsiung Wojcik, MD
Section2.bio: Monica is Clinical Genomic Analyst and a board-certified pediatrics physician who is now completing her combined fellowship training in genetics and neonatology through Boston Children's Hospital and Harvard Medical School. She is currently focused on gene discovery and improving genetic diagnostic rates, particularly in the neonatal population. She has an MD from Harvard Medical School.

Section2.name: Kristen Laricchia, MS
Section2.bio: Kristen is an Associate Computational Biologist who works on methods to identify variants in the mitochondrial genome to improve rare disease diagnosis.

Section2.name: Monkol Lek, PhD
Section2.bio: Monkol is an Assistant Professor of Genetics at Yale School of Medicine with affiliation at the Broad Institute. His group focuses on the development of computational methods for the analysis of genomic data from families with rare disease, particularly those with limb girdle muscular dystrophy.

Section2.name: Eric Liao, MD, PhD
Section2.bio: Dr. Liao is a plastic and reconstructive surgeon at Massachusetts General Hospital who is spearheading the Rare Genomes Project's craniofacial initiative. He is an assistant professor of surgery at Harvard Medical School, the director of the Cleft and Craniofacial Center at Massachusetts General Hospital, and the principal investigator at the Center for Regenerative Medicine at the Harvard Stem Cell Institute.

Section2.name: Alysia Lovgren, PhD
Section2.bio: Alysia leads the Analysis team for the Rare Genomes Project and is a Clinical Genomic Variant Scientist. Prior to joining the Broad, Alysia performed variant interpretation in the whole exome sequencing group at GeneDx.

Section2.name: Lauren Margolin
Section2.bio: Lauren is a Senior Project Manager at the Broad Institute. She is focused on building partnerships with patient advocacy groups to identify resources and connections to support the families who participate in the Rare Genomes Project.

Section2.name: Lynn Pais, MS
Section2.bio: Lynn is a Genomic Variant Analyst who performs exome and genome analyses for families with rare disease. She has a master’s degree in human genetics and previously worked as a project manager for a genetic research study at Brigham and Women’s Hospital.

Section2.name: Hana Snow
Section2.bio: Hana is a Software Engineer working on building tools to facilitate rare disease research. She is the lead developer for our rare disease analysis platform (seqr).

Section2.name: Matthew Solomonson, PhD
Section2.bio: Matt leads a software development team at the Broad. He is a Software Engineer interested in developing interactive visualization tools for exploring large biological datasets. He studied protein structural biology during his PhD at the University of British Columbia.

Section2.name: Miriam Udler, MD, PhD
Section2.bio: Miriam is Clinical Analyst and also a board-certified internal medicine and endocrinology physician who sees patients at Massachusetts General Hospital with a special focus on clinical endocrine genetics. She holds a PhD in Genetic Epidemiology from University of Cambridge.

Section2.name: Zaheer Valivullah
Section2.bio: Zaheer is a Genomic Variant Analyst conducting exome and genome analyses for families with rare disease. Before joining the Broad, he worked in the NIH’s Undiagnosed Diseases Program.

Section2.name: Grace VanNoy, MS, LGC
Section2.bio: Grace is a Clinical Project Manager for the Rare Genomes Project. She is a licensed, board-certified Genetic Counselor with a background in pediatric rare disease, gene discovery, and genomic sequencing.

Section2.name: Qingbo Wang
Section2.bio: Qingbo is a Genomic Analyst and Graduate Student from the Bioinformatics and Integrative Genomics PhD program at Harvard. He works on identifying multinucleotide variants, an important class of variants that are missed by standard calling pipelines.

Section2.name: Ben Weisburd
Section2.bio: Ben is a Software Engineer working on developing methods for interpreting DNA sequencing data in the context of severe Mendelian diseases. He developed our rare disease analysis platform (seqr).

Section2.name: Clara Williamson
Section2.bio: Clara is Clinical Project Coordinator for the Rare Genomes Project. She has a history in genetic disease research and is working on building out tools for patient outreach and communication. She is working at the Broad while applying to medical school.

Section3.name: Mike Wilson
Section3.bio: Mike is an Associate Computational Biologist working on the preliminary analyses of exomes and genomes to identify causal candidate genes and variants. He processes and quality checks the data that is generated for analysis.

AboutUsPage.ThanksBroad: Enormous thanks to our friends at Broad Institute's Data Donation Platform for their absolutely critical design, engineering, and technical work on this project. Raregenomes.org is powered by DDP's direct-to-patient study recruitment software.

ThanksPhotographer.Text1: All patient and family portraits on our website were photographed by Season Atwater, founder of
ThanksPhotographer.Text2: Thank you Season for being an amazing advocate for this community, and thank you to all of the families who so kindly shared their photos with us.
